explanation: Agent A is correct. Rule 2.2 forbids any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour. The statements (void) url; and (void) version; are expression-statements that have no side-effects for non-volatile pointer parameters; removing them would not change the program behaviour, so they meet the provided definition of dead code. (Of course such cast-to-void idioms are commonly used to silence unused-parameter warnings, but that does not change that they are dead code under the text of Rule 2.2 unless the expression evaluation had observable effects — e.g. the objects were volatile or evaluation could trap, which is not the case here.)
